column4: Those who conducted Paul brought him as far as Athens; and after receiving instructions to have Silas and Timothy join him as soon as possible
column5: they left him.

column4: While Paul was waiting for them in Athens
column5: he was deeply distressed to see that the city was full of idols.

column4: So he argued in the synagogue with the Jews and the devout persons
column5: and also in the marketplace every day with those who happened to be there.

column4: Also some Epicurean and Stoic philosophers debated with him. Some said
column5: "What does this babbler want to say?" Others said
column6: "He seems to be a proclaimer of foreign divinities." (This was because he was telling the good news about Jesus and the resurrection.)

column4: So they took him and brought him to the Areopagus and asked him
column5: "May we know what this new teaching is that you are presenting?

column4: It sounds rather strange to us
column5: so we would like to know what it means."

column4: Now all the Athenians and the foreigners living there would spend their time in nothing but telling or hearing something new.
Then Paul stood in front of the Areopagus and said
column5: "Athenians
column6: I see how extremely religious you are in every way.

column4: For as I went through the city and looked carefully at the objects of your worship
column5: I found among them an altar with the inscription
column6: 'To an unknown god.' What therefore you worship as unknown
column7: this I proclaim to you.

column4: The God who made the world and everything in it
column5: he who is Lord of heaven and earth
column6: does not live in shrines made by human hands

column4: nor is he served by human hands
column5: as though he needed anything
column6: since he himself gives to all mortals life and breath and all things.

column4: From one ancestor he made all nations to inhabit the whole earth
column5: and he allotted the times of their existence and the boundaries of the places where they would live

column4: so that they would search for God and perhaps grope for him and find him-- though indeed he is not far from each one of us.
For 'In him we live and move and have our being'; as even some of your own poets have said
column5: 'For we too are his offspring.'

column4: Since we are God's offspring
column5: we ought not to think that the deity is like gold
column6: or silver
column7: or stone
column8: an image formed by the art and imagination of mortals.

column4: While God has overlooked the times of human ignorance
column5: now he commands all people everywhere to repent

column4: because he has fixed a day on which he will have the world judged in righteousness by a man whom he has appointed
column5: and of this he has given assurance to all by raising him from the dead."

column4: When they heard of the resurrection of the dead
column5: some scoffed; but others said
column6: "We will hear you again about this."

column4: At that point Paul left them.
But some of them joined him and became believers
column5: including Dionysius the Areopagite and a woman named Damaris
column6: and others with them.

column4: After this Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.
There he found a Jew named Aquila
column5: a native of Pontus
column6: who had recently come from Italy with his wife Priscilla
column7: because Claudius had ordered all Jews to leave Rome. Paul went to see them

column4: and
column5: because he was of the same trade
column6: he stayed with them
column7: and they worked together-- by trade they were tentmakers.

column4: Every sabbath he would argue in the synagogue and would try to convince Jews and Greeks.
When Silas and Timothy arrived from Macedonia
column5: Paul was occupied with proclaiming the word
column6: testifying to the Jews that the Messiah was Jesus.

column4: When they opposed and reviled him
column5: in protest he shook the dust from his clothes and said to them

column4: Then he left the synagogue and went to the house of a man named Titius Justus
column5: a worshiper of God; his house was next door to the synagogue.

column4: Crispus
column5: the official of the synagogue
column6: became a believer in the Lord
column7: together with all his household; and many of the Corinthians who heard Paul became believers and were baptized.

column4: One night the Lord said to Paul in a vision
column5: "Do not be afraid
column6: but speak and do not be silent;

column4: for I am with you
column5: and no one will lay a hand on you to harm you
column6: for there are many in this city who are my people."

column4: He stayed there a year and six months
column5: teaching the word of God among them.

column4: But when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia
column5: the Jews made a united attack on Paul and brought him before the tribunal.

column4: They said
column5: "This man is persuading people to worship God in ways that are contrary to the law."

column4: Just as Paul was about to speak
column5: Gallio said to the Jews
column6: "If it were a matter of crime or serious villainy
column7: I would be justified in accepting the complaint of you Jews;

column4: but since it is a matter of questions about words and names and your own law
column5: see to it yourselves; I do not wish to be a judge of these matters."

column4: And he dismissed them from the tribunal.
Then all of them seized Sosthenes
column5: the official of the synagogue
column6: and beat him in front of the tribunal. But Gallio paid no attention to any of these things.

column4: After staying there for a considerable time
column5: Paul said farewell to the believers and sailed for Syria
column6: accompanied by Priscilla and Aquila. At Cenchreae he had his hair cut
column7: for he was under a vow.

column4: When they reached Ephesus
column5: he left them there
column6: but first he himself went into the synagogue and had a discussion with the Jews.

column4: When they asked him to stay longer
column5: he declined;

column4: but on taking leave of them
column5: he said
column6: "I will return to you
column7: if God wills." Then he set sail from Ephesus.

column4: When he had landed at Caesarea
column5: he went up to Jerusalem and greeted the church
column6: and then went down to Antioch.

column4: After spending some time there he departed and went from place to place through the region of Galatia and Phrygia
column5: strengthening all the disciples.

column4: Now there came to Ephesus a Jew named Apollos
column5: a native of Alexandria. He was an eloquent man
column6: well-versed in the scriptures.

column4: He had been instructed in the Way of the Lord; and he spoke with burning enthusiasm and taught accurately the things concerning Jesus
column5: though he knew only the baptism of John.

column4: He began to speak boldly in the synagogue; but when Priscilla and Aquila heard him
column5: they took him aside and explained the Way of God to him more accurately.

column4: And when he wished to cross over to Achaia
column5: the believers encouraged him and wrote to the disciples to welcome him. On his arrival he greatly helped those who through grace had become believers

column4: for he powerfully refuted the Jews in public
column5: showing by the scriptures that the Messiah is Jesus.

column4: While Apollos was in Corinth
column5: Paul passed through the interior regions and came to Ephesus
column6: where he found some disciples.

column4: He said to them
column5: "Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you became believers?" They replied
column6: "No
column7: we have not even heard that there is a Holy Spirit."

column4: Then he said
column5: "Into what then were you baptized?" They answered
column6: "Into John's baptism."

column4: Paul said
column5: "John baptized with the baptism of repentance
column6: telling the people to believe in the one who was to come after him
column7: that is

column4: On hearing this
column5: they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.

column4: When Paul had laid his hands on them
column5: the Holy Spirit came upon them
column6: and they spoke in tongues and prophesied--

column4: altogether there were about twelve of them.
He entered the synagogue and for three months spoke out boldly
column5: and argued persuasively about the kingdom of God.

column4: When some stubbornly refused to believe and spoke evil of the Way before the congregation
column5: he left them
column6: taking the disciples with him
column7: and argued daily in the lecture hall of Tyrannus.

column4: This continued for two years
column5: so that all the residents of Asia
column6: both Jews and Greeks
column7: heard the word of the Lord.

column4: God did extraordinary miracles through Paul
so that when the handkerchiefs or aprons that had touched his skin were brought to the sick
column5: their diseases left them
column6: and the evil spirits came out of them.

column4: Then some itinerant Jewish exorcists tried to use the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had evil spirits
column5: saying
column6: "I adjure you by the Jesus whom Paul proclaims."

column4: Seven sons of a Jewish high priest named Sceva were doing this.
But the evil spirit said to them in reply
column5: "Jesus I know
column6: and Paul I know; but who are you?"

column4: Then the man with the evil spirit leaped on them
column5: mastered them all
column6: and so overpowered them that they fled out of the house naked and wounded.

column4: When this became known to all residents of Ephesus
column5: both Jews and Greeks
column6: everyone was awestruck; and the name of the Lord Jesus was praised.

column4: Also many of those who became believers confessed and disclosed their practices.
A number of those who practiced magic collected their books and burned them publicly; when the value of these books was calculated
column5: it was found to come to fifty thousand silver coins.

column4: So the word of the Lord grew mightily and prevailed.
Now after these things had been accomplished
column5: Paul resolved in the Spirit to go through Macedonia and Achaia
column6: and then to go on to Jerusalem. He said
column7: "After I have gone there

column4: So he sent two of his helpers
column5: Timothy and Erastus
column6: to Macedonia
column7: while he himself stayed for some time longer in Asia.

column4: About that time no little disturbance broke out concerning the Way.
A man named Demetrius
column5: a silversmith who made silver shrines of Artemis
column6: brought no little business to the artisans.

column4: These he gathered together
column5: with the workers of the same trade
column6: and said
column7: "Men
column8: you know that we get our wealth from this business.

column4: You also see and hear that not only in Ephesus but in almost the whole of Asia this Paul has persuaded and drawn away a considerable number of people by saying that gods made with hands are not gods.
And there is danger not only that this trade of ours may come into disrepute but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis will be scorned
column5: and she will be deprived of her majesty that brought all Asia and the world to worship her."

column4: When they heard this
column5: they were enraged and shouted
column6: "Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!"

column4: The city was filled with the confusion; and people rushed together to the theater
column5: dragging with them Gaius and Aristarchus
column6: Macedonians who were Paul's travel companions.

column4: Paul wished to go into the crowd
column5: but the disciples would not let him;

column4: even some officials of the province of Asia
column5: who were friendly to him
column6: sent him a message urging him not to venture into the theater.

column4: Meanwhile
column5: some were shouting one thing
column6: some another; for the assembly was in confusion
column7: and most of them did not know why they had come together.

column4: Some of the crowd gave instructions to Alexander
column5: whom the Jews had pushed forward. And Alexander motioned for silence and tried to make a defense before the people.

column4: But when they recognized that he was a Jew
column5: for about two hours all of them shouted in unison
column6: "Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!"

column4: But when the town clerk had quieted the crowd
column5: he said
column6: "Citizens of Ephesus
column7: who is there that does not know that the city of the Ephesians is the temple keeper of the great Artemis and of the statue that fell from heaven?

column4: Since these things cannot be denied
column5: you ought to be quiet and do nothing rash.

column4: You have brought these men here who are neither temple robbers nor blasphemers of our goddess.
If therefore Demetrius and the artisans with him have a complaint against anyone
column5: the courts are open
column6: and there are proconsuls; let them bring charges there against one another.

column4: If there is anything further you want to know
column5: it must be settled in the regular assembly.

column4: For we are in danger of being charged with rioting today
column5: since there is no cause that we can give to justify this commotion."

column4: When he had said this
column5: he dismissed the assembly.

column4: After the uproar had ceased
column5: Paul sent for the disciples; and after encouraging them and saying farewell
column6: he left for Macedonia.

column4: When he had gone through those regions and had given the believers much encouragement
column5: he came to Greece

column4: where he stayed for three months. He was about to set sail for Syria when a plot was made against him by the Jews
column5: and so he decided to return through Macedonia.

column4: He was accompanied by Sopater son of Pyrrhus from Beroea
column5: by Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica
column6: by Gaius from Derbe
column7: and by Timothy
column8: as well as by Tychicus and Trophimus from Asia.

column4: They went ahead and were waiting for us in Troas;
but we sailed from Philippi after the days of Unleavened Bread
column5: and in five days we joined them in Troas
column6: where we stayed for seven days.

column4: On the first day of the week
column5: when we met to break bread
column6: Paul was holding a discussion with them; since he intended to leave the next day
column7: he continued speaking until midnight.

column4: There were many lamps in the room upstairs where we were meeting.
A young man named Eutychus
column5: who was sitting in the window
column6: began to sink off into a deep sleep while Paul talked still longer. Overcome by sleep
column7: he fell to the ground three floors below and was picked up dead.

column4: But Paul went down
column5: and bending over him took him in his arms
column6: and said
column7: "Do not be alarmed
column8: for his life is in him."

column4: Then Paul went upstairs
column5: and after he had broken bread and eaten
column6: he continued to converse with them until dawn; then he left.

column4: Meanwhile they had taken the boy away alive and were not a little comforted.
We went ahead to the ship and set sail for Assos
column5: intending to take Paul on board there; for he had made this arrangement
column6: intending to go by land himself.

column4: When he met us in Assos
column5: we took him on board and went to Mitylene.

column4: We sailed from there
column5: and on the following day we arrived opposite Chios. The next day we touched at Samos
column6: and the day after that we came to Miletus.

column4: For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus
column5: so that he might not have to spend time in Asia; he was eager to be in Jerusalem
column6: if possible
column7: on the day of Pentecost.

column4: From Miletus he sent a message to Ephesus
column5: asking the elders of the church to meet him.

column4: When they came to him
column5: he said to them: "You yourselves know how I lived among you the entire time from the first day that I set foot in Asia

column4: serving the Lord with all humility and with tears
column5: enduring the trials that came to me through the plots of the Jews.

column4: I did not shrink from doing anything helpful
column5: proclaiming the message to you and teaching you publicly and from house to house

column4: as I testified to both Jews and Greeks about repentance toward God and faith toward our Lord Jesus.
And now
column5: as a captive to the Spirit
column6: I am on my way to Jerusalem
column7: not knowing what will happen to me there

column4: except that the Holy Spirit testifies to me in every city that imprisonment and persecutions are waiting for me.
But I do not count my life of any value to myself
column5: if only I may finish my course and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus
column6: to testify to the good news of God's grace.

column4: "And now I know that none of you
column5: among whom I have gone about proclaiming the kingdom
column6: will ever see my face again.

column4: Therefore I declare to you this day that I am not responsible for the blood of any of you
for I did not shrink from declaring to you the whole purpose of God.
Keep watch over yourselves and over all the flock
column5: of which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers
column6: to shepherd the church of God that he obtained with the blood of his own Son.

column4: I know that after I have gone
column5: savage wolves will come in among you
column6: not sparing the flock.

column4: Some even from your own group will come distorting the truth in order to entice the disciples to follow them.
Therefore be alert
column5: remembering that for three years I did not cease night or day to warn everyone with tears.

column4: And now I commend you to God and to the message of his grace
column5: a message that is able to build you up and to give you the inheritance among all who are sanctified.

column4: I coveted no one's silver or gold or clothing.
You know for yourselves that I worked with my own hands to support myself and my companions.
In all this I have given you an example that by such work we must support the weak
column5: remembering the words of the Lord Jesus
column6: for he himself said
column7: 'It is more blessed to give than to receive.'"

column4: When he had finished speaking
column5: he knelt down with them all and prayed.

column4: There was much weeping among them all; they embraced Paul and kissed him
grieving especially because of what he had said
column5: that they would not see him again. Then they brought him to the ship.

column4: When we had parted from them and set sail
column5: we came by a straight course to Cos
column6: and the next day to Rhodes
column7: and from there to Patara.

column4: When we found a ship bound for Phoenicia
column5: we went on board and set sail.

column4: We came in sight of Cyprus; and leaving it on our left
column5: we sailed to Syria and landed at Tyre
column6: because the ship was to unload its cargo there.

column4: We looked up the disciples and stayed there for seven days. Through the Spirit they told Paul not to go on to Jerusalem.
When our days there were ended
column5: we left and proceeded on our journey; and all of them
column6: with wives and children
column7: escorted us outside the city. There we knelt down on the beach and prayed

column4: and said farewell to one another. Then we went on board the ship
column5: and they returned home.

column4: When we had finished the voyage from Tyre
column5: we arrived at Ptolemais; and we greeted the believers and stayed with them for one day.

column4: The next day we left and came to Caesarea; and we went into the house of Philip the evangelist
column5: one of the seven
column6: and stayed with him.

column4: He had four unmarried daughters who had the gift of prophecy.
While we were staying there for several days
column5: a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.

column4: He came to us and took Paul's belt
column5: bound his own feet and hands with it
column6: and said
column7: "Thus says the Holy Spirit
column8: 'This is the way the Jews in Jerusalem will bind the man who owns this belt and will hand him over to the Gentiles.'"

column4: When we heard this
column5: we and the people there urged him not to go up to Jerusalem.

column4: Then Paul answered
column5: "What are you doing
column6: weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be bound but even to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus."

column4: Since he would not be persuaded
column5: we remained silent except to say
column6: "The Lord's will be done."

column4: After these days we got ready and started to go up to Jerusalem.
Some of the disciples from Caesarea also came along and brought us to the house of Mnason of Cyprus
column5: an early disciple
column6: with whom we were to stay.

column4: When we arrived in Jerusalem
column5: the brothers welcomed us warmly.

column4: The next day Paul went with us to visit James; and all the elders were present.
After greeting them
column5: he related one by one the things that God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.

column4: When they heard it
column5: they praised God. Then they said to him
column6: "You see
column7: brother
column8: how many thousands of believers there are among the Jews
column9: and they are all zealous for the law.

column4: They have been told about you that you teach all the Jews living among the Gentiles to forsake Moses
column5: and that you tell them not to circumcise their children or observe the customs.

column4: What then is to be done? They will certainly hear that you have come.
So do what we tell you. We have four men who are under a vow.
Join these men
column5: go through the rite of purification with them
column6: and pay for the shaving of their heads. Thus all will know that there is nothing in what they have been told about you
column7: but that you yourself observe and guard the law.

column4: But as for the Gentiles who have become believers
column5: we have sent a letter with our judgment that they should abstain from what has been sacrificed to idols and from blood and from what is strangled and from fornication."

column4: Then Paul took the men
column5: and the next day
column6: having purified himself
column7: he entered the temple with them
column8: making public the completion of the days of purification when the sacrifice would be made for each of them.

column4: When the seven days were almost completed
column5: the Jews from Asia
column6: who had seen him in the temple
column7: stirred up the whole crowd. They seized him

column4: shouting
column5: "Fellow Israelites
column6: help! This is the man who is teaching everyone everywhere against our people
column7: our law
column8: and this place; more than that
column9: he has actually brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place."

column4: For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city
column5: and they supposed that Paul had brought him into the temple.

column4: Then all the city was aroused
column5: and the people rushed together. They seized Paul and dragged him out of the temple
column6: and immediately the doors were shut.

column4: While they were trying to kill him
column5: word came to the tribune of the cohort that all Jerusalem was in an uproar.

column4: Immediately he took soldiers and centurions and ran down to them. When they saw the tribune and the soldiers
column5: they stopped beating Paul.

column4: Then the tribune came
column5: arrested him
column6: and ordered him to be bound with two chains; he inquired who he was and what he had done.

column4: Some in the crowd shouted one thing
column5: some another; and as he could not learn the facts because of the uproar
column6: he ordered him to be brought into the barracks.

column4: When Paul came to the steps
column5: the violence of the mob was so great that he had to be carried by the soldiers.

column4: The crowd that followed kept shouting
column5: "Away with him!"

column4: Just as Paul was about to be brought into the barracks
column5: he said to the tribune
column6: "May I say something to you?" The tribune replied
column7: "Do you know Greek?

column4: Then you are not the Egyptian who recently stirred up a revolt and led the four thousand assassins out into the wilderness?"
Paul replied
column5: "I am a Jew
column6: from Tarsus in Cilicia
column7: a citizen of an important city; I beg you
column8: let me speak to the people."

column4: When he had given him permission
column5: Paul stood on the steps and motioned to the people for silence; and when there was a great hush
column6: he addressed them in the Hebrew language
column7: saying:

column4: "Brothers and fathers
column5: listen to the defense that I now make before you."

column4: When they heard him addressing them in Hebrew
column5: they became even more quiet. Then he said:

column4: "I am a Jew
column5: born in Tarsus in Cilicia
column6: but brought up in this city at the feet of Gamaliel
column7: educated strictly according to our ancestral law
column9: just as all of you are today.

column4: I persecuted this Way up to the point of death by binding both men and women and putting them in prison
as the high priest and the whole council of elders can testify about me. From them I also received letters to the brothers in Damascus
column5: and I went there in order to bind those who were there and to bring them back to Jerusalem for punishment.

column4: "While I was on my way and approaching Damascus
column5: about noon a great light from heaven suddenly shone about me.

column4: I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me
column5: 'Saul
column6: Saul
column7: why are you persecuting me?'

column4: I answered
column5: 'Who are you
column6: Lord?' Then he said to me
column7: 'I am Jesus of Nazareth whom you are persecuting.'

column4: Now those who were with me saw the light but did not hear the voice of the one who was speaking to me.
I asked
column5: 'What am I to do
column6: Lord?' The Lord said to me
column7: 'Get up and go to Damascus; there you will be told everything that has been assigned to you to do.'

column4: Since I could not see because of the brightness of that light
column5: those who were with me took my hand and led me to Damascus.

column4: "A certain Ananias
column5: who was a devout man according to the law and well spoken of by all the Jews living there

column4: came to me; and standing beside me
column5: he said
column6: 'Brother Saul
column7: regain your sight!' In that very hour I regained my sight and saw him.

column4: Then he said
column5: 'The God of our ancestors has chosen you to know his will
column6: to see the Righteous One and to hear his own voice;

column4: for you will be his witness to all the world of what you have seen and heard.
And now why do you delay? Get up
column5: be baptized
column6: and have your sins washed away
column7: calling on his name.'

column4: "After I had returned to Jerusalem and while I was praying in the temple
column5: I fell into a trance

column4: and saw Jesus saying to me
column5: 'Hurry and get out of Jerusalem quickly
column6: because they will not accept your testimony about me.'

column4: And I said
column5: 'Lord
column6: they themselves know that in every synagogue I imprisoned and beat those who believed in you.

column4: And while the blood of your witness Stephen was shed
column5: I myself was standing by
column6: approving and keeping the coats of those who killed him.'

column4: Then he said to me
column5: 'Go
column6: for I will send you far away to the Gentiles.'"

column4: Up to this point they listened to him
column5: but then they shouted
column6: "Away with such a fellow from the earth! For he should not be allowed to live."

column4: And while they were shouting
column5: throwing off their cloaks
column6: and tossing dust into the air

column4: the tribune directed that he was to be brought into the barracks
column5: and ordered him to be examined by flogging
column6: to find out the reason for this outcry against him.

column4: But when they had tied him up with thongs
column5: Paul said to the centurion who was standing by
column6: "Is it legal for you to flog a Roman citizen who is uncondemned?"

column4: When the centurion heard that
column5: he went to the tribune and said to him
column6: "What are you about to do? This man is a Roman citizen."

column4: The tribune came and asked Paul
column5: "Tell me
column6: are you a Roman citizen?" And he said
column7: "Yes."

column4: The tribune answered
column5: "It cost me a large sum of money to get my citizenship." Paul said
column6: "But I was born a citizen."

column4: Immediately those who were about to examine him drew back from him; and the tribune also was afraid
column5: for he realized that Paul was a Roman citizen and that he had bound him.

column4: Since he wanted to find out what Paul was being accused of by the Jews
column5: the next day he released him and ordered the chief priests and the entire council to meet. He brought Paul down and had him stand before them.

column4: While Paul was looking intently at the council he said
column5: "Brothers
column6: up to this day I have lived my life with a clear conscience before God."

column4: Then the high priest Ananias ordered those standing near him to strike him on the mouth.
At this Paul said to him
column5: "God will strike you
column6: you whitewashed wall! Are you sitting there to judge me according to the law
column7: and yet in violation of the law you order me to be struck?"

column4: Those standing nearby said
column5: "Do you dare to insult God's high priest?"

column4: And Paul said
column5: "I did not realize
column6: brothers
column7: that he was high priest; for it is written
column8: 'You shall not speak evil of a leader of your people.'"

column4: When Paul noticed that some were Sadducees and others were Pharisees
column5: he called out in the council
column6: "Brothers
column7: I am a Pharisee
column8: a son of Pharisees. I am on trial concerning the hope of the resurrection of the dead."

column4: When he said this
column5: a dissension began between the Pharisees and the Sadducees
column6: and the assembly was divided.

column4: (The Sadducees say that there is no resurrection
column5: or angel
column6: or spirit; but the Pharisees acknowledge all three.)

column4: Then a great clamor arose
column5: and certain scribes of the Pharisees' group stood up and contended
column6: "We find nothing wrong with this man. What if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him?"

column4: When the dissension became violent
column5: the tribune
column6: fearing that they would tear Paul to pieces
column7: ordered the soldiers to go down
column9: and bring him into the barracks.

column4: That night the Lord stood near him and said
column5: "Keep up your courage! For just as you have testified for me in Jerusalem
column6: so you must bear witness also in Rome."

column4: In the morning the Jews joined in a conspiracy and bound themselves by an oath neither to eat nor drink until they had killed Paul.
There were more than forty who joined in this conspiracy.
They went to the chief priests and elders and said
column5: "We have strictly bound ourselves by an oath to taste no food until we have killed Paul.

column4: Now then
column5: you and the council must notify the tribune to bring him down to you
column6: on the pretext that you want to make a more thorough examination of his case. And we are ready to do away with him before he arrives."

column4: Now the son of Paul's sister heard about the ambush; so he went and gained entrance to the barracks and told Paul.
Paul called one of the centurions and said
column5: "Take this young man to the tribune
column6: for he has something to report to him."

column4: So he took him
column5: brought him to the tribune
column6: and said
column7: "The prisoner Paul called me and asked me to bring this young man to you; he has something to tell you."

column4: The tribune took him by the hand
column5: drew him aside privately
column6: and asked
column7: "What is it that you have to report to me?"

column4: He answered
column5: "The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the council tomorrow
column6: as though they were going to inquire more thoroughly into his case.

column4: But do not be persuaded by them
column5: for more than forty of their men are lying in ambush for him. They have bound themselves by an oath neither to eat nor drink until they kill him. They are ready now and are waiting for your consent."

column4: So the tribune dismissed the young man
column5: ordering him
column6: "Tell no one that you have informed me of this."

column4: Then he summoned two of the centurions and said
column5: "Get ready to leave by nine o'clock tonight for Caesarea with two hundred soldiers
column6: seventy horsemen
column7: and two hundred spearmen.

column4: Also provide mounts for Paul to ride
column5: and take him safely to Felix the governor."

column4: He wrote a letter to this effect:
"Claudius Lysias to his Excellency the governor Felix
column5: greetings.

column4: This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them
column5: but when I had learned that he was a Roman citizen
column6: I came with the guard and rescued him.

column4: Since I wanted to know the charge for which they accused him
column5: I had him brought to their council.

column4: I found that he was accused concerning questions of their law
column5: but was charged with nothing deserving death or imprisonment.

column4: When I was informed that there would be a plot against the man
column5: I sent him to you at once
column6: ordering his accusers also to state before you what they have against him. "

column4: So the soldiers
column5: according to their instructions
column6: took Paul and brought him during the night to Antipatris.

column4: The next day they let the horsemen go on with him
column5: while they returned to the barracks.

column4: When they came to Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor
column5: they presented Paul also before him.

column4: On reading the letter
column5: he asked what province he belonged to
column6: and when he learned that he was from Cilicia

column4: he said
column5: "I will give you a hearing when your accusers arrive." Then he ordered that he be kept under guard in Herod's headquarters.

column4: Five days later the high priest Ananias came down with some elders and an attorney
column5: a certain Tertullus
column6: and they reported their case against Paul to the governor.

column4: When Paul had been summoned
column5: Tertullus began to accuse him
column6: saying: "Your Excellency
column7: because of you we have long enjoyed peace
column8: and reforms have been made for this people because of your foresight.

column4: We welcome this in every way and everywhere with utmost gratitude.
But
column5: to detain you no further
column6: I beg you to hear us briefly with your customary graciousness.

column4: We have
column5: in fact
column6: found this man a pestilent fellow
column7: an agitator among all the Jews throughout the world
column8: and a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes.

column4: He even tried to profane the temple
column5: and so we seized him.

column4: By examining him yourself you will be able to learn from him concerning everything of which we accuse him."
The Jews also joined in the charge by asserting that all this was true.
When the governor motioned to him to speak
column5: Paul replied: "I cheerfully make my defense
column6: knowing that for many years you have been a judge over this nation.

column4: As you can find out
column5: it is not more than twelve days since I went up to worship in Jerusalem.

column4: They did not find me disputing with anyone in the temple or stirring up a crowd either in the synagogues or throughout the city.
Neither can they prove to you the charge that they now bring against me.
But this I admit to you
column5: that according to the Way
column6: which they call a sect
column7: I worship the God of our ancestors
column8: believing everything laid down according to the law or written in the prophets.

column4: I have a hope in God-- a hope that they themselves also accept-- that there will be a resurrection of both the righteous and the unrighteous.
Therefore I do my best always to have a clear conscience toward God and all people.
Now after some years I came to bring alms to my nation and to offer sacrifices.
While I was doing this
column5: they found me in the temple
column6: completing the rite of purification
column7: without any crowd or disturbance.

column4: But there were some Jews from Asia-- they ought to be here before you to make an accusation
column5: if they have anything against me.

column4: Or let these men here tell what crime they had found when I stood before the council
unless it was this one sentence that I called out while standing before them
column5: 'It is about the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial before you today.'"

column4: But Felix
column5: who was rather well informed about the Way
column6: adjourned the hearing with the comment
column7: "When Lysias the tribune comes down

column4: Then he ordered the centurion to keep him in custody

So when they met here

column5: fearing that they would run on the Syrtis

column5: men

column4: After we had reached safety

column4: He

were written not for his sake alone,
Romans,4,24, but for ours also. It will be reckoned to us who believe in him who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead,
Romans,4,25, who was handed over to death for our trespasses and was raised for our justification.
Romans,5,1, Therefore, since we are justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ, 
Romans,5,2, through whom we have obtained access to this grace in which we stand; and we boast in our hope of sharing the glory of God. 
Romans,5,3, And not only that, but we also boast in our sufferings, knowing that suffering produces endurance, 
Romans,5,4, and endurance produces character, and character produces hope,
Romans,5,5, and hope does not disappoint us, because God's love has been poured into our hearts through the Holy Spirit that has been given to us.
Romans,5,6, For while we were still weak, at the right time Christ died for the ungodly.
Romans,5,7, Indeed, rarely will anyone die for a righteous person-- though perhaps for a good person someone might actually dare to die.
Romans,5,8, But God proves his love for us in that while we still were sinners Christ died for us.
Romans,5,9, Much more surely then, now that we have been justified by his blood, will we be saved through him from the wrath of God. 
Romans,5,10, For if while we were enemies, we were reconciled to God through the death of his Son, much more surely, having been reconciled, will we be saved by his life.
Romans,5,11, But more than that, we even boast in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received reconciliation.
Romans,5,12, Therefore, just as sin came into the world through one man, and death came through sin, and so death spread to all because all have sinned--
Romans,5,13, sin was indeed in the world before the law, but sin is not reckoned when there is no law.
Romans,5,14, Yet death exercised dominion from Adam to Moses, even over those whose sins were not like the transgression of Adam, who is a type of the one who was to come.
Romans,5,15, But the free gift is not like the trespass. For if the many died through the one man's trespass, much more surely have the grace of God and the free gift in the grace of the one man, Jesus Christ, abounded for the many.
Romans,5,16, And the free gift is not like the effect of the one man's sin. For the judgment following one trespass brought condemnation, but the free gift following many trespasses brings justification.
Romans,5,17, If, because of the one man's trespass, death exercised dominion through that one, much more surely will those who receive the abundance of grace and the free gift of righteousness exercise dominion in life through the one man, Jesus Christ.
Romans,5,18, Therefore just as one man's trespass led to condemnation for all, so one man's act of righteousness leads to justification and life for all.
Romans,5,19, For just as by the one man's disobedience the many were made sinners, so by the one man's obedience the many will be made righteous.
Romans,5,20, But law came in, with the result that the trespass multiplied; but where sin increased, grace abounded all the more,
Romans,5,21, so that, just as sin exercised dominion in death, so grace might also exercise dominion through justification leading to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord. 
Romans,6,1, What then are we to say? Should we continue in sin in order that grace may abound?
Romans,6,2, By no means! How can we who died to sin go on living in it?
Romans,6,3, Do you not know that all of us who have been baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death?
Romans,6,4, Therefore we have been buried with him by baptism into death, so that, just as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, so we too might walk in newness of life.
Romans,6,5, For if we have been united with him in a death like his, we will certainly be united with him in a resurrection like his.
Romans,6,6, We know that our old self was crucified with him so that the body of sin might be destroyed, and we might no longer be enslaved to sin.
Romans,6,7, For whoever has died is freed from sin.
Romans,6,8, But if we have died with Christ, we believe that we will also live with him.
Romans,6,9, We know that Christ, being raised from the dead, will never die again; death no longer has dominion over him.
Romans,6,10, The death he died, he died to sin, once for all; but the life he lives, he lives to God.
Romans,6,11, So you also must consider yourselves dead to sin and alive to God in Christ Jesus.
Romans,6,12, Therefore, do not let sin exercise dominion in your mortal bodies, to make you obey their passions.
Romans,6,13, No longer present your members to sin as instruments of wickedness, but present yourselves to God as those who have been brought from death to life, and present your members to God as instruments of righteousness. 
Romans,6,14, For sin will have no dominion over you, since you are not under law but under grace.
Romans,6,15, What then? Should we sin because we are not under law but under grace? By no means!
Romans,6,16, Do you not know that if you present yourselves to anyone as obedient slaves, you are slaves of the one whom you obey, either of sin, which leads to death, or of obedience, which leads to righteousness?
Romans,6,17, But thanks be to God that you, having once been slaves of sin, have become obedient from the heart to the form of teaching to which you were entrusted,
Romans,6,18, and that you, having been set free from sin, have become slaves of righteousness.
Romans,6,19, I am speaking in human terms because of your natural limitations. For just as you once presented your members as slaves to impurity and to greater and greater iniquity, so now present your members as slaves to righteousness for sanctification. 
Romans,6,20, When you were slaves of sin, you were free in regard to righteousness.
Romans,6,21, So what advantage did you then get from the things of which you now are ashamed? The end of those things is death.
Romans,6,22, But now that you have been freed from sin and enslaved to God, the advantage you get is sanctification. The end is eternal life.
Romans,6,23, For the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
Romans,7,1, Do you not know, brothers and sisters-- for I am speaking to those who know the law-- that the law is binding on a person only during that person's lifetime?
Romans,7,2, Thus a married woman is bound by the law to her husband as long as he lives; but if her husband dies, she is discharged from the law concerning the husband.
Romans,7,3, Accordingly, she will be called an adulteress if she lives with another man while her husband is alive. But if her husband dies, she is free from that law, and if she marries another man, she is not an adulteress.
Romans,7,4, In the same way, my friends, you have died to the law through the body of Christ, so that you may belong to another, to him who has been raised from the dead in order that we may bear fruit for God. 
Romans,7,5, While we were living in the flesh, our sinful passions, aroused by the law, were at work in our members to bear fruit for death.
Romans,7,6, But now we are discharged from the law, dead to that which held us captive, so that we are slaves not under the old written code but in the new life of the Spirit.
Romans,7,7, What then should we say? That the law is sin? By no means! Yet, if it had not been for the law, I would not have known sin. I would not have known what it is to covet if the law had not said, You shall not covet."

2 Corinthians,1,21, But it is God who establishes us with you in Christ and has anointed us,
2 Corinthians,1,22, by putting his seal on us and giving us his Spirit in our hearts as a first installment.

2 Corinthians,2,16, to the one a fragrance from death to death, to the other a fragrance from life to life. Who is sufficient for these things?
2 Corinthians,2,17, For we are not peddlers of God's word like so many; but in Christ we speak as persons of sincerity, as persons sent from God and standing in his presence.
2 Corinthians,3,1, Are we beginning to commend ourselves again? Surely we do not need, as some do, letters of recommendation to you or from you, do we?

2 Corinthians,3,6, who has made us competent to be ministers of a new covenant, not of letter but of spirit; for the letter kills, but the Spirit gives life.

2 Corinthians,3,9, For if there was glory in the ministry of condemnation, much more does the ministry of justification abound in glory!

2 Corinthians,3,12, Since, then, we have such a hope, we act with great boldness,

column5: and yet are well known; as dying
column6: and see-- we are alive; as punished
column7: and yet not killed;

column4: as sorrowful
column5: yet always rejoicing; as poor
column6: yet making many rich; as having nothing
column7: and yet possessing everything.

column4: We have spoken frankly to you Corinthians; our heart is wide open to you.
There is no restriction in our affections
column5: but only in yours.

column4: In return-- I speak as to children-- open wide your hearts also.
Do not be mismatched with unbelievers. For what partnership is there between righteousness and lawlessness? Or what fellowship is there between light and darkness?
What agreement does Christ have with Beliar? Or what does a believer share with an unbeliever?
What agreement has the temple of God with idols? For we are the temple of the living God; as God said
column5: "I will live in them and walk among them
column6: and I will be their God
column7: and they shall be my people.

column4: Therefore come out from them
column5: and be separate from them
column6: says the Lord
column7: and touch nothing unclean; then I will welcome you

column4: and I will be your father
column5: and you shall be my sons and daughters
column6: says the Lord Almighty."

column4: Since we have these promises
column5: beloved
column6: let us cleanse ourselves from every defilement of body and of spirit
column7: making holiness perfect in the fear of God.

column4: Make room in your hearts for us; we have wronged no one
column5: we have corrupted no one
column6: we have taken advantage of no one.

column4: I do not say this to condemn you
column5: for I said before that you are in our hearts
column6: to die together and to live together.

column4: I often boast about you; I have great pride in you; I am filled with consolation; I am overjoyed in all our affliction.
For even when we came into Macedonia
column5: our bodies had no rest
column6: but we were afflicted in every way-- disputes without and fears within.

column4: But God
column5: who consoles the downcast
column6: consoled us by the arrival of Titus

column4: and not only by his coming
column5: but also by the consolation with which he was consoled about you
column6: as he told us of your longing
column7: your mourning
column9: so that I rejoiced still more.

column4: For even if I made you sorry with my letter
column5: I do not regret it (though I did regret it
column6: for I see that I grieved you with that letter
column7: though only briefly).

column4: Now I rejoice
column5: not because you were grieved
column6: but because your grief led to repentance; for you felt a godly grief
column7: so that you were not harmed in any way by us.

column4: For godly grief produces a repentance that leads to salvation and brings no regret
column5: but worldly grief produces death.

column4: For see what earnestness this godly grief has produced in you
column5: what eagerness to clear yourselves
column6: what indignation
column7: what alarm
column10: what punishment! At every point you have proved yourselves guiltless in the matter.

column4: So although I wrote to you
column5: it was not on account of the one who did the wrong
column6: nor on account of the one who was wronged
column7: but in order that your zeal for us might be made known to you before God.

column4: In this we find comfort. In addition to our own consolation
column5: we rejoiced still more at the joy of Titus
column6: because his mind has been set at rest by all of you.

column4: For if I have been somewhat boastful about you to him
column5: I was not disgraced; but just as everything we said to you was true
column6: so our boasting to Titus has proved true as well.

column4: And his heart goes out all the more to you
column5: as he remembers the obedience of all of you
column6: and how you welcomed him with fear and trembling.

column4: I rejoice
column5: because I have complete confidence in you.

column4: We want you to know
column5: brothers and sisters
column6: about the grace of God that has been granted to the churches of Macedonia;

column4: for during a severe ordeal of affliction
column5: their abundant joy and their extreme poverty have overflowed in a wealth of generosity on their part.

column4: For
column5: as I can testify
column6: they voluntarily gave according to their means
column7: and even beyond their means

column4: begging us earnestly for the privilege of sharing in this ministry to the saints--
and this
column5: not merely as we expected; they gave themselves first to the Lord and
column6: by the will of God
column7: to us

column4: so that we might urge Titus that
column5: as he had already made a beginning
column6: so he should also complete this generous undertaking among you.

column4: Now as you excel in everything-- in faith
column5: in speech
column6: in knowledge
column7: in utmost eagerness
column8: and in our love for you-- so we want you to excel also in this generous undertaking.

column4: I do not say this as a command
column5: but I am testing the genuineness of your love against the earnestness of others.

column4: For you know the generous act of our Lord Jesus Christ
column5: that though he was rich
column6: yet for your sakes he became poor
column7: so that by his poverty you might become rich.

column4: And in this matter I am giving my advice: it is appropriate for you who began last year not only to do something but even to desire to do something--
now finish doing it
column5: so that your eagerness may be matched by completing it according to your means.

column4: For if the eagerness is there
column5: the gift is acceptable according to what one has-- not according to what one does not have.

column4: I do not mean that there should be relief for others and pressure on you
column5: but it is a question of a fair balance between

column4: your present abundance and their need
column5: so that their abundance may be for your need
column6: in order that there may be a fair balance.

column4: As it is written
column5: "The one who had much did not have too much
column6: and the one who had little did not have too little."

column4: But thanks be to God who put in the heart of Titus the same eagerness for you that I myself have.
For he not only accepted our appeal
column5: but since he is more eager than ever
column6: he is going to you of his own accord.

column4: With him we are sending the brother who is famous among all the churches for his proclaiming the good news;
and not only that
column5: but he has also been appointed by the churches to travel with us while we are administering this generous undertaking for the glory of the Lord himself and to show our goodwill.

column4: We intend that no one should blame us about this generous gift that we are administering
for we intend to do what is right not only in the Lord's sight but also in the sight of others.
And with them we are sending our brother whom we have often tested and found eager in many matters
column5: but who is now more eager than ever because of his great confidence in you.

column4: As for Titus
column5: he is my partner and co-worker in your service; as for our brothers
column6: they are messengers of the churches
column7: the glory of Christ.

column4: Therefore openly before the churches
column5: show them the proof of your love and of our reason for boasting about you.

column4: Now it is not necessary for me to write you about the ministry to the saints
for I know your eagerness
column5: which is the subject of my boasting about you to the people of Macedonia
column6: saying that Achaia has been ready since last year; and your zeal has stirred up most of them.

column4: But I am sending the brothers in order that our boasting about you may not prove to have been empty in this case
column5: so that you may be ready
column6: as I said you would be;

column4: otherwise
column5: if some Macedonians come with me and find that you are not ready
column6: we would be humiliated-- to say nothing of you-- in this undertaking.

column4: So I thought it necessary to urge the brothers to go on ahead to you
column5: and arrange in advance for this bountiful gift that you have promised
column6: so that it may be ready as a voluntary gift and not as an extortion.

column4: The point is this: the one who sows sparingly will also reap sparingly
column5: and the one who sows bountifully will also reap bountifully.

column4: Each of you must give as you have made up your mind
column5: not reluctantly or under compulsion
column6: for God loves a cheerful giver.

column4: And God is able to provide you with every blessing in abundance
column5: so that by always having enough of everything
column6: you may share abundantly in every good work.

column4: As it is written
column5: "He scatters abroad
column6: he gives to the poor; his righteousness endures forever."

column4: He who supplies seed to the sower and bread for food will supply and multiply your seed for sowing and increase the harvest of your righteousness.
You will be enriched in every way for your great generosity
column5: which will produce thanksgiving to God through us;

column4: for the rendering of this ministry not only supplies the needs of the saints but also overflows with many thanksgivings to God.
Through the testing of this ministry you glorify God by your obedience to the confession of the gospel of Christ and by the generosity of your sharing with them and with all others
while they long for you and pray for you because of the surpassing grace of God that he has given you.
Thanks be to God for his indescribable gift!
I myself
column5: Paul
column6: appeal to you by the meekness and gentleness of Christ-- I who am humble when face to face with you
column7: but bold toward you when I am away!--

column4: I ask that when I am present I need not show boldness by daring to oppose those who think we are acting according to human standards.
Indeed
column5: we live as human beings
column6: but we do not wage war according to human standards;

column4: for the weapons of our warfare are not merely human
column5: but they have divine power to destroy strongholds. We destroy arguments

column4: and every proud obstacle raised up against the knowledge of God
column5: and we take every thought captive to obey Christ.

column4: We are ready to punish every disobedience when your obedience is complete.
Look at what is before your eyes. If you are confident that you belong to Christ
column5: remind yourself of this
column6: that just as you belong to Christ
column7: so also do we.

column4: Now
column5: even if I boast a little too much of our authority
column6: which the Lord gave for building you up and not for tearing you down
column7: I will not be ashamed of it.

column4: I do not want to seem as though I am trying to frighten you with my letters.
For they say
column5: "His letters are weighty and strong
column6: but his bodily presence is weak
column7: and his speech contemptible."

column4: Let such people understand that what we say by letter when absent
column5: we will also do when present.

column4: We do not dare to classify or compare ourselves with some of those who commend themselves. But when they measure themselves by one another
column5: and compare themselves with one another
column6: they do not show good sense.

column4: We
column5: however
column6: will not boast beyond limits
column7: but will keep within the field that God has assigned to us
column8: to reach out even as far as you.

column4: For we were not overstepping our limits when we reached you; we were the first to come all the way to you with the good news of Christ.
We do not boast beyond limits
column5: that is
column6: in the labors of others; but our hope is that
column7: as your faith increases
column8: our sphere of action among you may be greatly enlarged

column4: so that we may proclaim the good news in lands beyond you
column5: without boasting of work already done in someone else's sphere of action.

column4: "Let the one who boasts
column5: boast in the Lord."

column4: For it is not those who commend themselves that are approved
column5: but those whom the Lord commends.

column4: I wish you would bear with me in a little foolishness. Do bear with me!
I feel a divine jealousy for you
column5: for I promised you in marriage to one husband
column6: to present you as a chaste virgin to Christ.

column4: But I am afraid that as the serpent deceived Eve by its cunning
column5: your thoughts will be led astray from a sincere and pure devotion to Christ.

column4: For if someone comes and proclaims another Jesus than the one we proclaimed
column5: or if you receive a different spirit from the one you received
column6: or a different gospel from the one you accepted
column7: you submit to it readily enough.

column4: I think that I am not in the least inferior to these super-apostles.
I may be untrained in speech
column5: but not in knowledge; certainly in every way and in all things we have made this evident to you.

column4: Did I commit a sin by humbling myself so that you might be exalted
column5: because I proclaimed God's good news to you free of charge?

column4: I robbed other churches by accepting support from them in order to serve you.
And when I was with you and was in need
column5: I did not burden anyone
column6: for my needs were supplied by the friends who came from Macedonia. So I refrained and will continue to refrain from burdening you in any way.

column4: As the truth of Christ is in me
column5: this boast of mine will not be silenced in the regions of Achaia.

column4: And why? Because I do not love you? God knows I do!
And what I do I will also continue to do
column5: in order to deny an opportunity to those who want an opportunity to be recognized as our equals in what they boast about.

column4: For such boasters are false apostles
column5: deceitful workers
column6: disguising themselves as apostles of Christ.

column4: And no wonder! Even Satan disguises himself as an angel of light.
So it is not strange if his ministers also disguise themselves as ministers of righteousness. Their end will match their deeds.
I repeat
column5: let no one think that I am a fool; but if you do
column6: then accept me as a fool
column7: so that I too may boast a little.

column4: What I am saying in regard to this boastful confidence
column5: I am saying not with the Lord's authority
column6: but as a fool;

column4: since many boast according to human standards
column5: I will also boast.

column4: For you gladly put up with fools
column5: being wise yourselves!

column4: For you put up with it when someone makes slaves of you
column5: or preys upon you
column6: or takes advantage of you
column7: or puts on airs
column8: or gives you a slap in the face.

column4: To my shame
column5: I must say
column6: we were too weak for that! But whatever anyone dares to boast of-- I am speaking as a fool-- I also dare to boast of that.

column4: Are they Hebrews? So am I. Are they Israelites? So am I. Are they descendants of Abraham? So am I.
Are they ministers of Christ? I am talking like a madman-- I am a better one: with far greater labors
column5: far more imprisonments
column6: with countless floggings
column7: and often near death.

column4: Five times I have received from the Jews the forty lashes minus one.
Three times I was beaten with rods. Once I received a stoning. Three times I was shipwrecked; for a night and a day I was adrift at sea;
on frequent journeys
column5: in danger from rivers
column6: danger from bandits
column7: danger from my own people
column12: danger from false brothers and sisters;

column4: in toil and hardship
column5: through many a sleepless night
column6: hungry and thirsty
column7: often without food

column4: And
column5: besides other things
column6: I am under daily pressure because of my anxiety for all the churches.

column4: Who is weak
column5: and I am not weak? Who is made to stumble
column6: and I am not indignant?

column4: If I must boast
column5: I will boast of the things that show my weakness.

column4: The God and Father of the Lord Jesus (blessed be he forever!) knows that I do not lie.
In Damascus
column5: the governor under King Aretas guarded the city of Damascus in order to seize me

column4: but I was let down in a basket through a window in the wall
column5: and escaped from his hands.

column4: It is necessary to boast; nothing is to be gained by it
column5: but I will go on to visions and revelations of the Lord.

column4: I know a person in Christ who fourteen years ago was caught up to the third heaven-- whether in the body or out of the body I do not know; God knows.
And I know that such a person-- whether in the body or out of the body I do not know; God knows--
was caught up into Paradise and heard things that are not to be told
column5: that no mortal is permitted to repeat.

column4: On behalf of such a one I will boast
column5: but on my own behalf I will not boast
column6: except of my weaknesses.

column4: But if I wish to boast
column5: I will not be a fool
column6: for I will be speaking the truth. But I refrain from it
column7: so that no one may think better of me than what is seen in me or heard from me

column4: even considering the exceptional character of the revelations. Therefore
column5: to keep me from being too elated
column6: a thorn was given me in the flesh
column7: a messenger of Satan to torment me
column8: to keep me from being too elated.

column4: Three times I appealed to the Lord about this
column5: that it would leave me

column4: but he said to me
column5: "My grace is sufficient for you
column6: for power is made perfect in weakness." So
column7: I will boast all the more gladly of my weaknesses
column8: so that the power of Christ may dwell in me.

column4: Therefore I am content with weaknesses
column5: insults
column6: hardships
column7: persecutions
column8: and calamities for the sake of Christ; for whenever I am weak

column4: I have been a fool! You forced me to it. Indeed you should have been the ones commending me
column5: for I am not at all inferior to these super-apostles
column6: even though I am nothing.

column4: The signs of a true apostle were performed among you with utmost patience
column5: signs and wonders and mighty works.

column4: How have you been worse off than the other churches
column5: except that I myself did not burden you? Forgive me this wrong!

column4: Here I am
column5: ready to come to you this third time. And I will not be a burden
column6: because I do not want what is yours but you; for children ought not to lay up for their parents
column7: but parents for their children.

column4: I will most gladly spend and be spent for you. If I love you more
column5: am I to be loved less?

column4: Let it be assumed that I did not burden you. Nevertheless (you say) since I was crafty
column5: I took you in by deceit.

column4: Did I take advantage of you through any of those whom I sent to you?
I urged Titus to go
column5: and sent the brother with him. Titus did not take advantage of you
column6: did he? Did we not conduct ourselves with the same spirit? Did we not take the same steps?

column4: Have you been thinking all along that we have been defending ourselves before you? We are speaking in Christ before God. Everything we do
column5: beloved
column6: is for the sake of building you up.

column4: For I fear that when I come
column5: I may find you not as I wish
column6: and that you may find me not as you wish; I fear that there may perhaps be quarreling
column7: jealousy

column4: I fear that when I come again
column5: my God may humble me before you
column6: and that I may have to mourn over many who previously sinned and have not repented of the impurity
column7: sexual immorality
column8: and licentiousness that they have practiced.

column4: This is the third time I am coming to you. "Any charge must be sustained by the evidence of two or three witnesses."
I warned those who sinned previously and all the others
column5: and I warn them now while absent
column6: as I did when present on my second visit
column7: that if I come again

column4: since you desire proof that Christ is speaking in me. He is not weak in dealing with you
column5: but is powerful in you.

column4: For he was crucified in weakness
column5: but lives by the power of God. For we are weak in him
column6: but in dealing with you we will live with him by the power of God.

column4: Examine yourselves to see whether you are living in the faith. Test yourselves. Do you not realize that Jesus Christ is in you?-- unless
column5: indeed
column6: you fail to meet the test!

column4: I hope you will find out that we have not failed.
But we pray to God that you may not do anything wrong-- not that we may appear to have met the test
column5: but that you may do what is right
column6: though we may seem to have failed.

column4: For we cannot do anything against the truth
column5: but only for the truth.

column4: For we rejoice when we are weak and you are strong. This is what we pray for
column5: that you may become perfect.

column4: So I write these things while I am away from you
column5: so that when I come
column6: I may not have to be severe in using the authority that the Lord has given me for building up and not for tearing down.

column4: Finally
column5: brothers and sisters
column6: farewell. Put things in order
column7: listen to my appeal
column9: live in peace; and the God of love and peace will be with you.

column4: Greet one another with a holy kiss.
All the saints greet you.
The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ
column5: the love of God
column6: and the communion of the Holy Spirit be with all of you.

column4: Paul an apostle-- sent neither by human commission nor from human authorities
column5: but through Jesus Christ and God the Father
column6: who raised him from the dead--

column4: and all the members of God's family who are with me
column5: To the churches of Galatia:

column4: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ
who gave himself for our sins to set us free from the present evil age
column5: according to the will of our God and Father

column4: to whom be the glory forever and ever. Amen.
I am astonished that you are so quickly deserting the one who called you in the grace of Christ and are turning to a different gospel--
not that there is another gospel
column5: but there are some who are confusing you and want to pervert the gospel of Christ.

column4: But even if we or an angel from heaven should proclaim to you a gospel contrary to what we proclaimed to you
column5: let that one be accursed!

column4: As we have said before
column5: so now I repeat
column6: if anyone proclaims to you a gospel contrary to what you received
column7: let that one be accursed!

column4: Am I now seeking human approval
column5: or God's approval? Or am I trying to please people? If I were still pleasing people
column6: I would not be a servant of Christ.

column4: For I want you to know
column5: brothers and sisters
column6: that the gospel that was proclaimed by me is not of human origin;

column4: for I did not receive it from a human source
column5: nor was I taught it
column6: but I received it through a revelation of Jesus Christ.

column4: You have heard
column5: no doubt
column6: of my earlier life in Judaism. I was violently persecuting the church of God and was trying to destroy it.

column4: I advanced in Judaism beyond many among my people of the same age
column5: for I was far more zealous for the traditions of my ancestors.

column4: But when God
column5: who had set me apart before I was born and called me through his grace
column6: was pleased

column4: to reveal his Son to me
column5: so that I might proclaim him among the Gentiles
column6: I did not confer with any human being

column4: nor did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were already apostles before me
column5: but I went away at once into Arabia
column6: and afterwards I returned to Damascus.

column4: Then after three years I did go up to Jerusalem to visit Cephas and stayed with him fifteen days;
but I did not see any other apostle except James the Lord's brother.
In what I am writing to you
column5: before God
column6: I do not lie!

column4: Then I went into the regions of Syria and Cilicia
and I was still unknown by sight to the churches of Judea that are in Christ;
they only heard it said
column5: "The one who formerly was persecuting us is now proclaiming the faith he once tried to destroy."

column4: And they glorified God because of me.
Then after fourteen years I went up again to Jerusalem with Barnabas
column5: taking Titus along with me.

column4: I went up in response to a revelation. Then I laid before them (though only in a private meeting with the acknowledged leaders) the gospel that I proclaim among the Gentiles
column5: in order to make sure that I was not running
column6: or had not run
column7: in vain.

column4: But even Titus
column5: who was with me
column6: was not compelled to be circumcised
column7: though he was a Greek.

column4: But because of false believers secretly brought in
column5: who slipped in to spy on the freedom we have in Christ Jesus
column6: so that they might enslave us--

column4: we did not submit to them even for a moment
column5: so that the truth of the gospel might always remain with you.

column4: And from those who were supposed to be acknowledged leaders (what they actually were makes no difference to me; God shows no partiality)-- those leaders contributed nothing to me.
On the contrary
column5: when they saw that I had been entrusted with the gospel for the uncircumcised
column6: just as Peter had been entrusted with the gospel for the circumcised

column4: (for he who worked through Peter making him an apostle to the circumcised also worked through me in sending me to the Gentiles)
and when James and Cephas and John
column5: who were acknowledged pillars
column6: recognized the grace that had been given to me
column7: they gave to Barnabas and me the right hand of fellowship
column8: agreeing that we should go to the Gentiles and they to the circumcised.

column4: They asked only one thing
column5: that we remember the poor
column6: which was actually what I was eager to do.

column4: But when Cephas came to Antioch
column5: I opposed him to his face
column6: because he stood self-condemned;

column4: for until certain people came from James
column5: he used to eat with the Gentiles. But after they came
column6: he drew back and kept himself separate for fear of the circumcision faction.

column4: And the other Jews joined him in this hypocrisy
column5: so that even Barnabas was led astray by their hypocrisy.

column4: But when I saw that they were not acting consistently with the truth of the gospel
column5: I said to Cephas before them all
column6: "If you
column7: though a Jew
column8: live like a Gentile and not like a Jew
column9: how can you compel the Gentiles to live like Jews?"

column4: We ourselves are Jews by birth and not Gentile sinners;
yet we know that a person is justified not by the works of the law but through faith in Jesus Christ. And we have come to believe in Christ Jesus
column5: so that we might be justified by faith in Christ
column6: and not by doing the works of the law
column7: because no one will be justified by the works of the law.

column4: But if
column5: in our effort to be justified in Christ
column6: we ourselves have been found to be sinners
column7: is Christ then a servant of sin? Certainly not!

column4: But if I build up again the very things that I once tore down
column5: then I demonstrate that I am a transgressor.

column4: For through the law I died to the law
column5: so that I might live to God. I have been crucified with Christ;

column4: and it is no longer I who live
column5: but it is Christ who lives in me. And the life I now live in the flesh I live by faith in the Son of God
column6: who loved me and gave himself for me.

column4: I do not nullify the grace of God; for if justification comes through the law
column5: then Christ died for nothing.

column4: You foolish Galatians! Who has bewitched you? It was before your eyes that Jesus Christ was publicly exhibited as crucified!
The only thing I want to learn from you is this: Did you receive the Spirit by doing the works of the law or by believing what you heard?
Are you so foolish? Having started with the Spirit
column5: are you now ending with the flesh?

column4: Did you experience so much for nothing?-- if it really was for nothing.
Well then
column5: does God supply you with the Spirit and work miracles among you by your doing the works of the law
column6: or by your believing what you heard?

column4: Just as Abraham "believed God
column5: and it was reckoned to him as righteousness
column6:
Galatians,3,7, so, you see, those who believe are the descendants of Abraham.
Galatians,3,8, And the scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, declared the gospel beforehand to Abraham, saying, All the Gentiles shall be blessed in you."

column4: For this reason
column5: those who believe are blessed with Abraham who believed.

column4: For all who rely on the works of the law are under a curse; for it is written
column5: "Cursed is everyone who does not observe and obey all the things written in the book of the law."

column4: Now it is evident that no one is justified before God by the law; for "The one who is righteous will live by faith."
But the law does not rest on faith; on the contrary
column5: "Whoever does the works of the law will live by them."

column4: Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law by becoming a curse for us-- for it is written
column5: "Cursed is everyone who hangs on a tree"--

column4: in order that in Christ Jesus the blessing of Abraham might come to the Gentiles
column5: so that we might receive the promise of the Spirit through faith.

column4: Brothers and sisters
column5: I give an example from daily life: once a person's will has been ratified
column6: no one adds to it or annuls it.

column4: Now the promises were made to Abraham and to his offspring; it does not say

column7:
that is, to one person, who is Christ. 
Galatians,3,17, My point is this: the law, which came four hundred thirty years later, does not annul a covenant previously ratified by God, so as to nullify the promise.
Galatians,3,18, For if the inheritance comes from the law, it no longer comes from the promise; but God granted it to Abraham through the promise.
Galatians,3,19, Why then the law? It was added because of transgressions, until the offspring would come to whom the promise had been made; and it was ordained through angels by a mediator. 
Galatians,3,20, Now a mediator involves more than one party; but God is one.
Galatians,3,21, Is the law then opposed to the promises of God? Certainly not! For if a law had been given that could make alive, then righteousness would indeed come through the law.
Galatians,3,22, But the scripture has imprisoned all things under the power of sin, so that what was promised through faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who believe. 
Galatians,3,23, Now before faith came, we were imprisoned and guarded under the law until faith would be revealed.
Galatians,3,24, Therefore the law was our disciplinarian until Christ came, so that we might be justified by faith.
Galatians,3,25, But now that faith has come, we are no longer subject to a disciplinarian,
Galatians,3,26, for in Christ Jesus you are all children of God through faith.
Galatians,3,27, As many of you as were baptized into Christ have clothed yourselves with Christ.
Galatians,3,28, There is no longer Jew or Greek, there is no longer slave or free, there is no longer male and female; for all of you are one in Christ Jesus.
Galatians,3,29, And if you belong to Christ, then you are Abraham's offspring, heirs according to the promise. 
Galatians,4,1, My point is this: heirs, as long as they are minors, are no better than slaves, though they are the owners of all the property;
Galatians,4,2, but they remain under guardians and trustees until the date set by the father.
Galatians,4,3, So with us; while we were minors, we were enslaved to the elemental spirits of the world. 
Galatians,4,4, But when the fullness of time had come, God sent his Son, born of a woman, born under the law,
Galatians,4,5, in order to redeem those who were under the law, so that we might receive adoption as children.
Galatians,4,6, And because you are children, God has sent the Spirit of his Son into our hearts, crying, Abba! Father!"

Ephesians,4,31, Put away from you all bitterness and wrath and anger and wrangling and slander, together with all malice,

Ephesians,5,1, Therefore be imitators of God, as beloved children,
Ephesians,5,2, and live in love, as Christ loved us and gave himself up for us, a fragrant offering and sacrifice to God.
